fields.description: currently the console offers IAM options to anyone with the name "admin", we can do this so that anyone who has the policy permissions for IAM would see IAM.

comments.body: We can do read access checks for resources, but beyond that, we'd need to have dry_run enabled for modify operations if we wanted to test access to those up front.

To minimize the cost of the API calls, we can use a filter to ensure no data is returned. We should verify that the proper permissions checks will be done so we can use this to validate read-access for users and groups (and maybe roles)

It seems that the way IAM permissions checks are done on the ListUsers, ListGroups, ListRoles calls allows those calls to return properly, but only showing resources the user has access to (so, only themselves on the users list, worst case).
Unsure if this differs from how AWS-IAM does things.
We may need to re-think access to the IAM pages, showing them always but they won't show data if permission isn't there. [~jloza]
[~dkavanagh] can you check against what AWS does? This may be a bug in Euca. If not, let's re-think.

Found this in AWS docs:

"Permissions for Working in the AWS Management Console

The preceding examples show policies that allow a user to perform the actions using the command line interface (CLI), the AWS SDKs, or the APIs. If users want to use the AWS Management Console to administer users, groups, and permissions, they need additional permissions. As users work with the console, it issues requests to IAM to list users and groups, to get the policies associated with a user or group, to get account information, and so on.

For example, if user Bob wants to use the AWS Management Console to change his own access keys, he starts by going to the console and clicking Users. This gesture causes the console to make a ListUsers request. If Bob doesn't have permission for the iam:ListUsers action, the console will be denied access when it tries to list users. As a result, Bob can't get to his own name and to his own access keys, even if he has permissions for the CreateAccessKey and UpdateAccessKey actions.

If you want to give users permissions to work in the AWS Management Console to administer users, groups, and credentials, you need to include permissions for the actions that the console performs in the console. The policies that are listed later in this topic include examples that show how to perform tasks using the console and using the CLI or API."

I did a test with my personal AWS account. I have a user with access to all ec2 and s3 API calls, but no access to iam api calls. I provided access to iam calls, then removed it and got different results from the ListUsers call; >>> conn.get_all_users() {u'list_users_response': {u'response_metadata': {u'request_id': u'73989c9c-02f2-11e4-98ae-730180a2854f'}, u'list_users_result': {u'users': [{u'path': u'/', u'create_date': u'2011-08-11T16:14:22Z', u'user_id': u'AIDAJECF7FJRYZ3K5BUWY', u'arn': u'arn:aws:iam::365812321051:user/dak', u'user_name': u'dak'}, {u'path': u'/', u'create_date': u'2012-04-25T00:29:15Z', u'user_id': u'AIDAJH24VY4OZU5YXU3FQ', u'arn': u'arn:aws:iam::365812321051:user/daktest', u'user_name': u'daktest'}], u'is_truncated': u'false'}}} >>> conn.get_all_users() Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/boto-v2.13.2-py2.7.egg/boto/iam/connection.py", line 311, in get_all_users return self.get_response('ListUsers', params, list_marker='Users') File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/boto-v2.13.2-py2.7.egg/boto/iam/connection.py", line 76, in get_response raise self.ResponseError(response.status, response.reason, body) boto.exception.BotoServerError: BotoServerError: 403 Forbidden Sender AccessDenied User: arn:aws:iam::365812321051:user/daktest is not authorized to perform: iam:ListUsers on resource: arn:aws:iam::365812321051:user/ bf3c2b57-02f2-11e4-a268-09f034a192f3

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/820

per the PR comment, I'd like to get this work merged in to reduce my overhead till the blocking bug is fixed (likely in Sprint 2). Once reviewed, pls return to "confirmed" for me to complete it later.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/881

to properly test, need cloud built from current #testing
Older clouds will show IAM access for all users, but data shown will be limited and access to operations will be halted at back-end, so no security risk.
[~dkavanagh]: Code review passed, but I may have jumped the gun on merging PR 881.  Did it go through UX review with [~jloza]?
I didn't pass to Jenny since there was zero change to the user interface. It is all under the hood.
Yep, no user-visible changes = no need for UX review. :)

[~dkavanagh]: I'm not exactly sure how to test this.  Can you give me some pointers?  Do I need to install an older version of Eucalyptus to compare to the current version?  Perhaps we can go over this in real time.

The best way to test this is to use a policy that limits access to a single IAM resource, like users or roles. We test for read access for users, groups, roles independently and allow access to those resource pages based on that test.
